refsection.title: DESCRIPTION
refsection.para: Gets/sets view parameters in local units. The view command accepts the following subcommands:

listitem.para: Get (without arguments) or set the azimuth, elevation, and (optional) twist. If only 2 arguments are supplied, a twist of 0 is assumed. The -i flag can be use to set the AET incrementally. Setting the azimuth and elevation also changes the eye point while keeping the center and view size static.
Aligns the eye point with a desired point and the current view center (eye -> pt -> center). The -i flag can be used to align from the opposite direction (eye -> center -> pt).
Resets the view size and view center such that all displayed objects are within the view.
Get (without arguments) or set the view center. Setting the center also changes the eye point while keeping the azimuth, elevation, and view size static.

Get (witout arguments) or set the view in the form of a vector and optional twist. Setting the direction also changes the azimuth, elevation, and eye point while keeping the center and view size static. The -i flag can be used to negate all values (for both getting and setting).
Get (without arguments) or set the eye point. Setting the eye point also changes center while keeping the azimuth, elevation, and view size static.
Adjusts the current view such that the eye is looking in the direction of the given coordinates, but does not move the eye point nor change the view size.
Get (witout arguments) or set the view in the form of a quarternion. Setting the quarternion also changes the azimuth, elevation, and eye point while keeping the center and view size static.
Saves the current viewing parameters in the specified file in the form of a shell script that will run the BRL-CAD rt program.
Get (without arguments) or set the view size. Setting the view size also changes the eye point while keeping the azimuth, elevation, and center static.

Get (witout arguments) or set the view in the form of yaw, pitch, roll. A ypr of 0 0 0 is a rear view (AE = 180, 0). Setting the ypr also changes the azimuth, elevation, and eye point while keeping the center and view size static.
